titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of the Oscar Stonorov papers, 1912-1978 (bulk 1929-1970)
titlestmt.author: Processed by Laura Jackson

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Wyoming. American Heritage Center.

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Laura Jackson February 2010

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: University of Wyoming. American Heritage Center.

did.abstract: Contains materials documenting Stonorov's career as an architect and city planner.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in six series. Most series are arranged alphabetically except for the correspondence, for which there is an alphabetical index.

bioghist.head: Biography of Oscar Stonorov
bioghist.p: Oscar [Oskar] Stonorov (1905-1970), an architect and sculptor, emigrated to the United States from Germany in 1929 and settled in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in the early 1930s. He was interested throughout his career in public housing and affordable housing for the working classes. His architectural associates included Alfred Kastner, Louis I. Kahn, George Howe, and Frank Haws. In addition to numerous projects in Philadelphia and the northeastern U.S., Stonorov was the designer of the Frank Lloyd Wright exhibit which toured the U.S. and major European cities in 1951-1952. He was the principal designer of the United Auto Workers headquarters building in Detroit, Michigan and the UAW's Black Lake Conference Center in Onaway, Michigan. Stonorov and his long-time friend, UAW President Walter Reuther died in a plane crash in 1970 while inspecting the Black Lake construction site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Oscar Stonorov papers document Stonorov’s career as architect and city planner. Much of the material pertains to architectural and artistic projects including Stonorov’s home (Avon Lea), the Carl Mackley Housing Project, Philadelphia city planning projects, exhibits such as “Frank Lloyd Wright“ and “Better Philadelphia,” and sculptures. Materials include drawings, notes, photographs, reports, and correspondence. The correspondence series chiefly concerns various construction and urban planning projects, but there is personal correspondence as well. There is an alphabetical index for the general correspondence.

The collection also contains speeches, papers, and articles written by Stonorov expressing his views on design and urban planning. In addition there is material from conferences, round tables, interviews, and forums with which Stonorov was involved. Also included are subject and research files and newspaper clippings on Stonorov’s work and colleagues, and biographical material such as resumes, articles about Stonorov, and photographs of him.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions on the materials for research purposes, and the collection is open to the public.

userestrict.head: Copyright Information
userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for observing all copyright, property, and libel laws as they apply.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: There are no known other archival collections created by Oscar Stonorov at the date of processing.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This material was received from Elizabeth and Katrina Stonorov, Frederick Gutheim, Nancy Grace, and Susan Cole between 1971-2005.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Laura Jackson in February 2010.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Item Description, Box Number, Folder Number, Collection Name, Collection Number, American Heritage Center, University of Wyoming.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital reproductions of select material from this collection are available at http://digitalcollections.uwyo.edu:8180/luna/servlet/uwydbuwy~79~79.

scopecontent.p: Contains information on buildings, city planning, exhibits, and sculptures. It includes photographs, financial data and reports relating to projects.
Contains drawings, notes, reports, plans, photos, clippings, and correspondence for buildings and city planning projects by Stonorov and his architectural firms.

scopecontent.p: Contains speeches and papers presented at various conferences. Also includes published articles written by Stonorov. Folder titles may reflect the paper title or the conference where it was presented.

did.unittitle: The Coming Reconstruction of American Cities
How Much House for Your Money
Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Architecture (speech)
Meaning and Mechanics of the Demonstration Cities Program
Symposium on the Architecture of the City

scopecontent.p: Contains materials relating to international, national, and regional architectural issues with which Stonorov was involved. It includes transcripts from forums and roundtables; minutes, agendas, and proceedings from committees and conferences; materials from professional organizations; and other materials relating to Stonorov's involvement in issues on architecture and city planning.

scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains information on Stonorov's colleagues, papers and reports written by others, photographs, and research on aging.
